Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Health volunteers in rural Ethiopia: Discourses and experiences of status, motivation, and wellbeing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Kenneth Maes of Oregon State University, in collaboration with Dr. Svea Closser of Middlebury College, will undertake research to advance understanding of the effects of volunteering on individuals' psycho-social well-being. Many poor countries rely heavily on unpaid and low-paid labor for internationally funded health-development projects. Low-level, underpaid work is often thought to be exploitative and demoralizing, but health-development project planners often claim that low-level employment and volunteerism in this sector bolster workers' psychological well-being and social status. Although studies conducted in western contexts provide support for links among altruistic behavior (including volunteering), social status, and mental well-being, these links have not been rigorously examined in non-western, low-income contexts. This research will test these links in one such context: Ethiopia.

Using social science methods such as interviews, document analysis, participant observation, and survey methods, this study will address three main questions: (1) What material and immaterial benefits do low-level workers in Ethiopia seek through providing their labor to health-development projects? (2) To what extent and in what ways do social respect and mental or spiritual satisfaction accrue to poor, low-status workers? (3) How do assumptions that low-level workers gain such benefits function to justify forms of unpaid and low-paid employment, from the varied perspectives of international donor organizations and project implementers, local government officials, and workers themselves?

To answer these questions, the project will focus on a rural health-development project in Ethiopia that aims to improve maternal and newborn survival, and that connects one of the wealthiest donor organizations in the world with the Ethiopian Ministry of Health and Ethiopian community health workers. The project will thus examine labor policies and the experiences and well-being of workers within a global health-development economy that links international, national, and local actors.

The potential broader impacts of this research are quite substantial and include strengthening collaborations with Ethiopian scholars, providing research experiences to U.S. undergraduates, who will accompany the PIs to the field, and providing information to policymakers and officials in organizations that utilize volunteer labor. This project was supported by the Cultural Anthropology Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering's Global Venture Fund.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Like other low-income countries, Ethiopia has both a critical lack of health workers and high maternal and infant mortality. Ethiopia’s leaders and international donors have attempted to address both of these problems through training Community Health Workers to provide essential health care to their neighbors.

Two Community Health Worker programs were created to bridge human resource gaps in Ethiopia’s health sector. Health Extension Workers are women with at least ten years of schooling who come from the same rural areas that they serve (FMOH 2007). From rural health posts, they offer services including immunization, prenatal care, and treatment for diseases like tuberculosis. They receive a salary of about $100/month. But there are not enough of these workers: each serves a population of at least several thousand.

So, in 2011, the government started a new program called the Women’s Development Army. One woman out of every five households would become a Women’s Development Army leader. These leaders were chosen for being “model women,” for having adopted a lifestyle deemed “healthy” and “development-minded”—for doing things like immunizing their children and sending their daughters to school. They are supposed to assist Health Extension Workers in providing health services. These Women’s Development Army leaders are not paid anything, and in fact foreign donors have been asked not to provide them any incentives lest they become habituated to payment.

Our research was interested in several interrelated questions about the Women’s Development Army: How is unpaid labor by very poor women justified? Do assumptions that impoverished workers enhance their psychosocial well-being through pursuing goal of saving lives function to justify forms of employment that may be in some ways exploitative? And, do psychosocial benefits, such as social respect, spirituality, and mental satisfaction, motivate and actually accrue to materially-impoverished workers? We were interested in whether volunteering helped women gain social status or opportunities for economic advancement.

These questions are important because the women who make up the Women’s Development Army are drawn from one of the world’s poorest populations, and because answering them can shed light on the sustainability and success of major human resource policies and practices within the health systems of low-income countries. Our research found that many of these volunteers had concerns about having enough water to drink and food to eat. Many highly desired increased access to income in their daily lives.  Our research describes the lives and concerns of these workers so that policies and programs can hopefully be created that provide them with better support, bolstering their own well-being and their abilities to serve the needs of their communities.

 This project included international capacity building and collaboration with Ethiopian colleagues who were involved in all stages of the project. It also assisted in improving undergraduate education, involving 8 undergraduates at Middlebury College in the process of data collection, analysis, and dissemination. Five of these students visited Ethiopia to conduct fieldwork. Data and analyses will be made available to contacts within the Ethiopian public health system and their global partners.
